div.l: Deth drough þe tappe of lyf and lete it gone
And eủere sithen hath so þe tappe y ronne
Til that almost al empty is þe tonne
The streem of lyf now droppeþ on the chymbe
The sely tonge may wel rynge ⁊and chymbe
Of wrecchedenesse þat passid is ful yore
With old folk saue dotage is no more
¶ Whan that oure oost had herd þis s̉ermonyng
He gan to speken as lordely as a kyng
He seide what amonteþ alle þis witte
What schal we speke alday of holy writte
The deuel made a Reue for to p̉reche
Or of a souter shipman or a leche
Sey forth þi tale and tarye nouȝt þe tyme
Loo depford and it is halfwey pryme
Loo Grenewich þat many a shrewe is Inne
It were al tyme þi tale for to gynne
// Now sires qduod þis Osewold þe Reue
I pray yow alle þat ye nouȝt ye yow greue
Þough I Answere and somdel sette his houwe
For leueful it is wiþ force force of shouwe
This dronken mellere hath I told vs here
How þat bigiled was a Carpentere
ꝐPar auenture in skorn for I am oon
And by youre leue I shal hym quyte anoon
Right in his cherlies termes wil I speke
I prey to god his nekke mote to breke
He can wel in myn Eye seen a stalke
But in his owne he can nouȝt seen a balke
Here endith the ꝓprolog //
And begynneth the tale
AT Trumpyngton̄ nouȝt fer fro Caumbrygge
Ther goth a broke and oủer that a brygge
Vppon þe whiche brooke þ̉er stant a melle
And þis is v̉erray soth þat I yow telle
A Mellere was þ̉er dwelling many a day
As any pecok he was proud and gay
Pipen he couthe and fisshen ⁊and nettes bete
And torne coppes and wel wrastel ⁊and shete
Ay bi his belt he bar a long panade
And of a swerd ful trenchant was þe blade
A Ioly popper bar he in his pouche
